content.raw: I thin that the render should be available in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=ftu&tut=ftu3&branch=ftu_gui but images are not being displayed. Is this a bug or I'm doing something wrong?
content.html: I thin that the render should be available in http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=ftu&tut=ftu3&branch=ftu_gui but images are not being displayed. Is this a bug or I'm doing something wrong?

content.raw:
The images are redirecting to `/ftu3/files`, which doesn't exist:

#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/raw/ftu_gui/ftu3/files/ftu3-boot-screen.png

If you change to `/ftu/files`, they show up:

#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/raw/ftu_gui/ftu/files/ftu3-boot-screen.png

What I don't understand is why the link to `tut=ftu3` works:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=ftu&tut=ftu3&branch=ftu_gui 

But not the one to `tut=ftu`, which I think should be the correct one:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=ftu&tut=ftu&branch=ftu_gui
content.html:

If you change to /ftu/files, they show up:

What I don't understand is why the link to tut=ftu3 works:

http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=ftu&tut=ftu3&branch=ftu_gui

But not the one to tut=ftu, which I think should be the correct one:

content.raw:
Using the word `static` here might be misleading. Static has a specific meaning in Gazebo, that is, it doesn't move due to physics. And this word can be seen in the left panel, in the model editor...

There are non static models which don't have joints and there are static models with joints (but the joints don't move...).
content.html:
Using the word static here might be misleading. Static has a specific meaning in Gazebo, that is, it doesn't move due to physics. And this word can be seen in the left panel, in the model editor...

There are non static models which don't have joints and there are static models with joints (but the joints don't move...).

content.raw:
I just meant that if the image gets compressed to, say, 600 px, then the icons might end up too small. So if we had a small window to begin with, there would be little to compress.

But I was just playing with it and there's not much room to compress the width, because of the bottom toolbar. So it should be fine as it is.

content.raw:
Probably we should improve the behaviour of the right panel. But right now, it displays the joints for the currently selected model, whether that model is static or not. 

If no model is selected, nothing shows. 

If forces are applied to the joints of a static model, they won't move (but they show on the panel).
content.html:
Probably we should improve the behaviour of the right panel. But right now, it displays the joints for the currently selected model, whether that model is static or not.

If no model is selected, nothing shows.

If forces are applied to the joints of a static model, they won't move (but they show on the panel).

content.raw:
Hm, agreed that we should spend some time on the right panel.

In the meantime, would this fix be correct? 

"The right panel...open it. The right panel can be used to interact with the mobile parts of a selected model (the
joints). If there are no models selected  in the Scene, the panel does not display any information. Currently,
if forces are applied to a static model (meaning it is not affected by physics), the model will not move."
content.html:
Hm, agreed that we should spend some time on the right panel.

In the meantime, would this fix be correct?

"The right panel...open it. The right panel can be used to interact with the mobile parts of a selected model (the joints). If there are no models selected in the Scene, the panel does not display any information. Currently, if forces are applied to a static model (meaning it is not affected by physics), the model will not move."

content.raw: It's correct. I'd suggest we don't even mention static models not to confuse new users, but I'm fine either way.
content.html: It's correct. I'd suggest we don't even mention static models not to confuse new users, but I'm fine either way.

content.raw: Since we are taking a paragraph to explain RTF, I wonder if it would be worth it to mention what iterations are and that the "Steps" correspond to iterations.
content.html: Since we are taking a paragraph to explain RTF, I wonder if it would be worth it to mention what iterations are and that the "Steps" correspond to iterations.

content.raw: Do you have a suggestion for how we might explain those?
content.html: Do you have a suggestion for how we might explain those?

content.raw:
Hummm some rewording of this?:

The physical state of the world in Gazebo is calculated once per iteration. You can see the number of iterations on the right side of the bottom toolbar. By default, each iteration is equivalent to 1 ms of simulation time. You can press the pause button to pause the simulation and step through a few steps at a time using the step button.
content.html:
Hummm some rewording of this?:

The physical state of the world in Gazebo is calculated once per iteration. You can see the number of iterations on the right side of the bottom toolbar. By default, each iteration is equivalent to 1 ms of simulation time. You can press the pause button to pause the simulation and step through a few steps at a time using the step button.
